summary: This document is an email chain from August 2020 discussing the status of American Express financial records production for the Epstein investigation. It references a prior July 2019 production of card transaction data and account files, and includes internal discussion about accessing and sharing specific files with defense counsel.

persons.name: Kristina Hendrickson
persons.context: American Express employee who shared financial records folder with investigators in July 2019 and communicated about file access issues.

persons.name: Alex
persons.context: Recipient of American Express financial records from Kristina Hendrickson in July 2019, mentioned in email correspondence.

persons.name: Yui Chow
persons.context: Mentioned by Kristina Hendrickson as someone who may have sent documents to investigators.

persons.name: Maurene
persons.context: Internal email sender in August 2020 seeking Amex credentials to access original production files.

persons.context: Mentioned as working with Maurene and Eric to access Amex files.

events.title: American Express Financial Records Production
events.description: Kristina Hendrickson of American Express sends financial records including transaction data and account information for Epstein's cards to investigator Alex via email and shared folder.

events.title: Internal Discussion About Amex File Access
events.description: Internal email chain among investigators discussing access issues with American Express production files and whether to request missing files or produce existing files to defense counsel.

keyFacts: American Express provided extensive financial records for Jeffrey Epstein's accounts including multiple card types (Platinum, Centurion, Gold, Business Plum, Blue Cash) in July 2019.
The production included Excel files with transaction data, PDF mainframe reports, and a 'Key Transactions' analysis file that may have identified particular people.
Investigators in August 2020 were having technical difficulties accessing some original .vsf files and were considering whether to produce them directly to defense counsel.
The American Express employee explicitly stated the documents were 'for investigative use and not for court proceedings'.
The email chain shows ongoing logistical challenges in managing and sharing large volumes of financial evidence in the Epstein investigation.
